1282 Index

Insertion Sort

Sort cards in your hand one at a time

Imagine sorting a hand of playing cards. You pick up one card at a time and insert it into its correct position among the cards you've already sorted.

How It Works

  1. Start with the second element (first is 'sorted')
  2. Compare current element with sorted elements to its left
  3. Shift larger elements right to make room
  4. Insert the element in its correct position
  5. Repeat for all remaining elements

Complexity

  • Time Best: O(n) - already sorted
  • Time Avg: O(n²)
  • Time Worst: O(n²) - reverse sorted
  • Space: O(1) - in-place

When to Use

  • Small arrays (< 50 elements)
  • Nearly sorted data
  • Online sorting (data arrives one at a time)
  • Simple implementation needed

Quicksort

Pick a pivot, put smaller left, larger right, repeat

Choose one person as the 'pivot'. Everyone shorter goes left, everyone taller goes right. Now repeat for each group.

How It Works

  1. Pick a pivot element (often last element)
  2. Partition: move smaller elements left, larger right
  3. Pivot is now in its final position
  4. Recursively sort left and right partitions

Complexity

  • Time Best: O(n log n)
  • Time Avg: O(n log n)
  • Time Worst: O(n²) - rare with good pivot
  • Space: O(log n) - recursion stack

When to Use

  • General-purpose sorting
  • Average case matters most
  • In-place sorting needed
  • Cache efficiency important
